title: INVENTORY / GREATEST INNOSSENCE
description: "The Greatest Innocence" by João Paolo Salomao Lopez de Fuego.

dialogueTree.title: The Greatest Innocence: ""The Greatest Innocence" by João Pa..."
dialogueTree.text: "The Greatest Innocence" by João Paolo Salomao Lopez de Fuego. The book is large and heavy.

links.title: You: "Crack open this immense tome."
links.text: Crack open this immense tome.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "You can't. The idea of coming face..."
links.text: You can't. The idea of coming face to face with the *Greatest Innocence* fills you with immense sadness and dread now.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Dora..."
links.text: Dora...

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Browsing through the various chapte..."
links.text: Browsing through the various chapters, you try your best to understand the ceaseless overflow -- the sprawl -- of names, dates, places, events historical. Most of it ends up as a twisted mass of facts inside your brain.

links.title: Endurance: "You can do it. It'll be worth it. T..."
links.text: You can do it. It'll be worth it. There's something here.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Your educational survey is done. Di..."
links.text: Your educational survey is done. Did you catch any of that? No? Oh well, it's pop quiz time! Let's see what you've learned. This might take a few minutes. You ready?

links.title: You: "Sure, why not?"
links.text: Sure, why not?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "That's the spirit. Here we go! Ques..."
links.text: That's the spirit. Here we go! Question 1: Who was the first innocence?

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Oh yeah, this is what I was made fo..."
links.text: Oh yeah, this is what I was made for.

links.title: You: "That so? Alright, go on, give me al..."
links.text: That so? Alright, go on, give me all the hints you got.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "A pop quiz is a short examination d..."
links.text: A pop quiz is a short examination designed to test your knowledge without any prior warning or announcement. Such exams allow the teacher to assess how thoroughly the students have retained the material at hand -- voila! Now blast that first innocence!

links.title: Half Light: "Thanks for nothing."
links.text: Thanks for nothing.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Dolores Dei! Dolores..."
links.text: Dolores Dei! Dolores...

links.title: You: "Sola?"
links.text: Sola?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. Sola was anointed during..."
links.text: Incorrect. Sola was anointed during the previous century and even lived to see the current one.  She was an urban planner who spoke her mind and largely left history to its own devices, encouraging people to excel on their own rather than prescribing to a deified model of history. She is often called an *anti-innocence*.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Sola resigned after an assassinatio..."
links.text: Sola resigned after an assassination attempt by a Yugo nationalist, who blamed her for not taking the side of the left during the turn of the century revolutions. (Innocences don't usually resign). Care to try again?

links.title: You: "Dolores Dei?"
links.text: Dolores Dei?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. Dolores Dei was the inno..."
links.text: Incorrect. Dolores Dei was the innocence of humanism, internationalism, and the welfare state. She codified parliamentary democracy and created modern institutions, among these the Moralintern. She was powerful. And beautiful, on all her icons...

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Her colours are silver, white, and..."
links.text: Her colours are silver, white, and apricot. And when you think her name, Dolores, stomach acid rises to the back of your throat and it hurts -- you see a flash silver, a wreath, an airport bag. And blonde hair, you don't know why. Another choice, perhaps?

links.title: Inland Empire: "Steer clear of this one. There's so..."
links.text: Steer clear of this one. There's something terrible about this one.

links.title: You: "What?"
links.text: What?

links.title: Inland Empire: "A strange sensation of loss. When s..."
links.text: A strange sensation of loss. When she left the Earth, the dust and the ice and the humans... That is unimportant to the quiz. Stop thinking about this.

links.title: You: "Not thinking about it. Not thinking..."
links.text: Not thinking about it. Not thinking about it. Back to quiz.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Yes. The quiz is impersonal. No nee..."
links.text: Yes. The quiz is impersonal. No need to rouse *sensations* in yourself at the mention of Dolores Dei. Who was the *first* innocence -- it wasn't Dolores Dei...

links.title: You: "The Perikarnassian?"
links.text: The Perikarnassian?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Correct! Nothing much is known abou..."
links.text: Correct! Nothing much is known about him. It's not even clear that he was a *he*, but Franconegro presumed as such and called him Pius. He's depicted as a young man with molten gold pouring out of his mouth -- all he spoke was gold. It's said he *invented* god; and equality of men before god. He also introduced the gold standard as a way for measuring people's love for aurum.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "As the first innocence, he declared..."
links.text: As the first innocence, he declared that there should be more of those like him. It is presumed his disciples were the beginning of the Holy Party (the Founding Party).

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Question 2: Who was the strongest i..."
links.text: Question 2: Who was the strongest innocence?

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Easy! Everybody knows the answer to..."
links.text: Easy! Everybody knows the answer to this. You, me, anybody.

links.title: You: "Doesn't sound too familiar to me, s..."
links.text: Doesn't sound too familiar to me, shoot me a hint.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "An innocence is the highest categor..."
links.text: An innocence is the highest category of historical personage in the world, a literal personification of History. Traditionally, an innocence, when anointed, assumes supreme rule over the Occident, or the known world in general -- at least the parts that matter.

links.title: You: "Okay, very interesting, but that do..."
links.text: Okay, very interesting, but that doesn't help me answer the question.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Um... I can do better! Okay, so com..."
links.text: Um... I can do better! Okay, so commonly an innocence does not enforce his or her power through military power. This is seen as unnecessary. The innocence wins because an innocence can't help but win, for their deeds are inevitabilities. Did this help?

links.title: You: "No."
links.text: No.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Damn."
links.text: Damn.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Dolores..."
links.text: Dolores...

links.title: You: "Yes. Immensely."
links.text: Yes. Immensely.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Great!"
links.text: Great!

links.title: You: "Vesper-Messina?"
links.text: Vesper-Messina?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. Vesper-Messina is not a..."
links.text: Incorrect. Vesper-Messina is not a person, but a defunct state on the southeastern coast of the Occident. It used to take up most of the peninsula, before separating into the Republics of Vesper and Messina. Care to try again?

links.title: You: "Franconegro?"
links.text: Franconegro?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Correct! Named the innocence of mil..."
links.text: Correct! Named the innocence of militarism, he codified hereditary rule -- but at the same time ended serfdom and established the interisolary reál as the global reserve currency. He also established the concept of the Nation.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Franconegro attempted to solve the..."
links.text: Franconegro attempted to solve the rising tensions between the aristocracy and bourgeoisie by building a unified society, in which every man has a place and a mission, but at the same time may rise to nobility provided on the strength of his virtue.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Question 3: Who was the false innoc..."
links.text: Question 3: Who was the false innocence?

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Got it under control. No problem. S..."
links.text: Got it under control. No problem. Solid on this one. It's wide-spread historical information.

links.title: You: "All news to me, so maybe a few hint..."
links.text: All news to me, so maybe a few hints?

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Yes. There exists a group called th..."
links.text: Yes. There exists a group called the Founding Party. Known as the Holy Party during the time of the Perikarnassian. This, the world's oldest international organization, spends its time in search of either the re-emergence of the innocence, or new members.

links.title: You: "Sigh internally."
links.text: Sigh internally.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "There seems to be a mix-up with the..."
links.text: There seems to be a mix-up with the sources. It's not my fault.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "At least it clearly wasn't Dolores..."
links.text: At least it clearly wasn't Dolores Dei. She wouldn't be *false*. She's beautiful.

links.title: You: "Ernö Pasternak?"
links.text: Ernö Pasternak?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Correct! There have been a number o..."
links.text: Correct! There have been a number of counter- or false-innocences -- some assumed to have innocentic qualities, some who just thought so themselves. Occasionally they have the support of a faction inside the ecclesiastic organization, and accusations of foul play have arisen...

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "The most famous -- and important --..."
links.text: The most famous -- and important -- of these  was Ernö Pasternak. He was into torture, despotism, hymns, cannons, and world conquest, but got defeated and humiliated by Stepan the Despicable of Kedra.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Final stretch, you've come so far a..."
links.text: Final stretch, you've come so far and learned so much. This is the most important one. Question 4: Who was the *greatest* innocence? The most *important* of them all. The most precious to human kind...

links.title: Encyclopedia: "I've got it! Honest."
links.text: I've got it! Honest.

links.title: You: "You sound confident, go right ahead..."
links.text: You sound confident, go right ahead -- a hint would come in handy.

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Of course! This is my *thing*, the..."
links.text: Of course! This is my *thing*, the reason I exist in this world. The correct answer is Franconegro.

links.title: You: "You're *absolutely* certain of this..."
links.text: You're *absolutely* certain of this?

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Zero doubts."
links.text: Zero doubts.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "While it was actually her..."
links.text: While it was actually her...

links.title: You: "Franconegro."
links.text: Franconegro.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. While Franconegro built..."
links.text: Incorrect. While Franconegro built concrete churches and cathedrals, and while many people, especially the Mesque, consider him a father figure due to his militarism and nationalism, João Paolo Salomao Lopez de Fuego argues differently. Another choice, perhaps?

links.title: Encyclopedia: "Oh yes, militarism and nationalism..."
links.text: Oh yes, militarism and nationalism -- my bad.

links.title: Logic: "Yes. Obviously."
links.text: Yes. Obviously.

links.title: You: "Ernö Pasternak."
links.text: Ernö Pasternak.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. He was a violent bastard..."
links.text: Incorrect. He was a violent bastard out to torture, maim and kill whoever stood in his way. He was also a *false* innocence, disqualifying him from being the greatest and most important -- and most precious to human kind. Would you like to try again?

links.title: You: "Dolores Dei."
links.text: Dolores Dei.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Correct! The Mesque might see Franc..."
links.text: Correct! The Mesque might see Franconegro as the father of nations, but as of this century there's been a great shift in attitude -- Dolores Dei has become widely regarded as the greatest innocence. A most radical change to the whole fabric of the world.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Everything from interisolary travel..."
links.text: Everything from interisolary travel, to the connected world, to three consecutive scientific revolutions can be traced back to her. Every decade that passes she seems less human somehow -- and more beautiful...

links.title: Pain Threshold: "And more beautiful, and *more* beau..."
links.text: And more beautiful, and *more* beautiful...

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Congratulations on finishing the te..."
links.text: Congratulations on finishing the test. The results and your subsequent grade have been calculated. You get...

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "... an A. All correct. Impressive,..."
links.text: ... an A. All correct. Impressive, *oddly* so.

links.title: Inland Empire: "You would have done better if you'd..."
links.text: You would have done better if you'd just left Dolores Dei for the end. Dial the Dolores Dei down *a bit*.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "But endless tries aren't really fai..."
links.text: But endless tries aren't really fair, don't you think?

links.title: You: ""Still got it, book!""
links.text: "Still got it, book!"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant is doing his best to..."
links.text: The lieutenant is doing his best to ignore your behaviour.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Yeah, sure. It's so much easier onc..."
links.text: Yeah, sure. It's so much easier once you know the answers, right?

links.title: You: "Close the book. [Leave.]"
links.text: Close the book. [Leave.]

links.title: You: ""Oh damn it, what went wrong this t..."
links.text: "Oh damn it, what went wrong this time."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant is tapping his foot,..."
links.text: The lieutenant is tapping his foot, but you can't tell if it's a habitual tic or impatience.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "How is it possible that you're mess..."
links.text: How is it possible that you're messing this up? Are you doing it on purpose?

links.title: You: ""Aced that. Take that, you book.""
links.text: "Aced that. Take that, you book."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant is jolted to attenti..."
links.text: The lieutenant is jolted to attention by your sudden outburst. "Huh? Take what?"

links.title: You: ""I put this book in it's place, tha..."
links.text: "I put this book in it's place, that's what. I'm so goddamn smart."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""A-ha." The lieutenant looks at you..."
links.text: "A-ha." The lieutenant looks at you with his usual lithic mask of a face.

links.title: You: ""Never mind. Thinking aloud.""
links.text: "Never mind. Thinking aloud."

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "You are really just talking to your..."
links.text: You are really just talking to yourself. It is quite silly.

links.title: You: ""Good enough! Take that, you book.""
links.text: "Good enough! Take that, you book."

links.title: You: ""Damn you, you arrogant book.""
links.text: "Damn you, you arrogant book."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant is jolted awake by y..."
links.text: The lieutenant is jolted awake by your furious cursing. "What's going on with you?"

links.title: You: ""Thinks it's so smart, god damn...""
links.text: "Thinks it's so smart, god damn..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Oh-kay." The lieutenant stares at..."
links.text: "Oh-kay." The lieutenant stares at you, his visage unflinching.

links.title: You: ""The book is unfair.""
links.text: "The book is unfair."

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "You are shouting at an inanimate ob..."
links.text: You are shouting at an inanimate object like a real weirdo. No wonder you seem to have trouble with the right answers.

links.title: Horrific Necktie: "Man, something's weird about this b..."
links.text: Man, something's weird about this book. You should do something fun instead. Rock out, forget about it.

links.title: Inland Empire: "You would have done better if you'd..."
links.text: You would have done better if you'd just dial the Dolores Dei down a bit.

links.title: Inland Empire: "You really navigated some treachero..."
links.text: You really navigated some treacherous waters here. Well done.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "I don't even have to say it anymore..."
links.text: I don't even have to say it anymore.

links.title: You: "Kedra?"
links.text: Kedra?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. Kedra is a large nation..."
links.text: Incorrect. Kedra is a large nation in the mid-northern area of the Mundi isola, north of the Occident, between the Irmalan mountain range and the Pisantic *mare interregnum*. Care to try again?

links.title: You: "Stepan the Despicable?"
links.text: Stepan the Despicable?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. Stepan the Despicable, r..."
links.text: Incorrect. Stepan the Despicable, regent of Kedra, was a ruler who conquered the known world during the Kedreatic Conquest -- *instead* of the despotic Ernö Pasternak. Would you try again?

links.title: You: "Dolores..."
links.text: Dolores...

links.title: Pain Threshold: "No. Stop thinking it. I said it was..."
links.text: No. Stop thinking it. I said it wasn't her. She was true.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Okay. It wasn't Dolores Dei. She's..."
links.text: Okay. It wasn't Dolores Dei. She's not false.

links.title: You: "Dolores Dei?"
links.text: Dolores Dei?

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect again. While she originat..."
links.text: Incorrect again. While she originated many modern institutions, launched several successful expeditions, and was even critical of the innocentic system itself -- and *somehow* keeps popping up in your mind! -- she is not often considered the *strongest*.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Even though the words most associat..."
links.text: Even though the words most associated with her rule are *l'amour, la compassion, l'autodiscipline* -- love, compassion, self-control -- which could be seen as facets of strength. Would you like to try again?

links.title: Inland Empire: "Please. Relax."
links.text: Please. Relax.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Just steer clear of this one, okay...."
links.text: Just steer clear of this one, okay. There's something terrible about this one.

links.title: You: "What?"
links.text: What?

links.title: Inland Empire: "Who knows? You feel like you *lost*..."
links.text: Who knows? You feel like you *lost* her somehow. When she left the Earth, the dust and the ice and the humans... This is unimportant to the quiz. Stop thinking about this.

links.title: You: "Not thinking about it. Not thinking..."
links.text: Not thinking about it. Not thinking about it. Back to quiz.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Yes. The quiz is impersonal. No nee..."
links.text: Yes. The quiz is impersonal. No need to rouse *sensations* in yourself at the mention of Dolores Dei. Who was the *first* innocence -- it wasn't her.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Incorrect. While she originated man..."
links.text: Incorrect. While she originated many modern institutions, launched several successful expeditions, and was even critical of the innocentic system itself -- not to mention *beautiful* -- she is not often considered the *strongest*.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Dolores..."
links.text: Dolores...

links.title: You: "You know, I didn't really absorb an..."
links.text: You know, I didn't really absorb anything from what I just read.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Then go with your best guess! Isn't..."
links.text: Then go with your best guess! Isn't that what students are trained to do when they don't know the answer?

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Dolores Dei!"
links.text: Dolores Dei!

links.title: You: "Oh god no, let me out of here."
links.text: Oh god no, let me out of here.

links.title: The Greatest Innocence: "Disappointing. You'll never get any..."
links.text: Disappointing. You'll never get anywhere with that attitude.

links.title: You: "[Put the book away.]"
links.text: [Put the book away.]
